newsitem.title: GERMANY: F.O. LICHT - Daily sugar report.
newsitem.headline: F.O. LICHT - Daily sugar report.

text.p: The following is a direct contribution from statistician F.O. Licht in Ratzeburg, Germany. Please address any queries to Helmut Ahlfeld on +00 49 4541 88920.

White sugar futures in London finished firmer although light buying failed to pull prices above the psychological $300 per tonne level. March ended $0.50 stronger at $298.50, while May added $0.40 to close at $298.30 per tonne. There were no fresh fundamental news to influence prices. In New York raw sugar futures ended marginally higher in quiet trade. Speculative short covering gave the market an initial boost while locals were also light buyers. However, steady trade selling kept prices below resistance at 10.40 cents/lb for March delivery. March added 1 point to close at 10.31 cents/lb, while May closed 3 points higher at 10.45 cents/lb. The outer months added 2 to 5 points.

Physical brokers said that in the whites market there is no the danger that poorer quality sugar from Poland will be delivered against the No. 5 London white sugar contract which reduces the market's overall deliverable quality. Poland this season has an export surplus of more than 400,000 tonnes. Another worry for the whites market are the two new refineries in the Middle East churning out sugar and Indian exports which have covered demand in places where perhaps traditional EU-quality sugar would go. Traders said that although the spot value of the No. 5 contract currently stands at the lowest levels since February 1994, buyers have been reluctant to emerge and key players on the demand side such as Russia have still to make their requirements clear.

GERMANY - Sugar consumption in October 1996, the first month of the 1996/97 campaign (October/September), amounted to 296,616 tonnes, up from 290,690 tonnes in October 1995. Total consumption in 1995/96 reached 3.076 million tonnes compared to 2.995 million tonnes in 1994/95 and 2.940 million tonnes in 1993/94. Sugar imports in August 1996 amounted to 9,415 tonnes, down from 23,058 tonnes in August 1995. This brought cumulative imports in the first 11 months of 1995/96 (October/August) up to 196,447 tonnes compared to 201,705 tonnes in the corresponding period the previous year. Total imports in 1994/95 reached 225,848 tonnes against 213,664 tonnes in 1993/94. Major countries of origin in October/August 1995/96 were France with 143,112 tonnes whites against 148,539 tonnes and the Netherlands with 13,249 tonnes compared to 12,573 tonnes. Sugar exports in August 1996 amounted 68,732 tonnes, down from 108,896 tonnes exported in August 1995. This brought cumulative exports in October/August 1995/96 up to 1.249 million tonnes compared to 1.401 million tonnes in the like period the previous year. Total exports in 1994/95 reached 1.452 million tonnes against 1.922 million tonnes in 1993/94.

Major countries of destination in October/August 1995/96 were Belgium-Luxembourg with 154,678 tonnes whites, up from 74,250 tonnes, the United Arab Emirates with 119,715 tonnes compared to 155,602 tonnes and Switzerland with 83,953 tonnes, down from 93,355 tonnes.

MALAYSIA - Sugar imports in August 1996 reached 100,177 tonnes, slightly down from last year's 111,463 tonnes. This brought cumulative imports in the first eight months of 1996 (January/August) up to 709,344 tonnes compared to 683,374 tonnes in the corresponding period the previous year. Total imports in 1995 amounted to the record high of 1.033 million tonnes, up from 959,518 tonnes in 1994. Major countries of origin in January/August 1996 were Thailand with 366,600 tonnes raws against 249,576 tonnes, Australia with 293,194 tonnes, down from 376,580 tonnes and South Africa with 33,000 tonnes against nil. Sugar exports in August 1996 amounted to 11,767 tonnes, down from 20,920 tonnes in August 1995. This brought cumulative exports in January/August 1996 up to 77,724 tonnes compared 78,957 tonnes in the like period the previous year. Total exports in 1995 reached 123,561 tonnes, down from 159,525 tonnes in the like period the previous year. Major countries of destination in January/August 1996 were Singapore with 46,063 tonnes whites and Indonesia with 18,748 tonnes.
Tunisia bought a cargo of white sugar for August shipment at $328.75 per tonne, trade sources said. Further details were not immediately available.
